VOL. XVII, NO. 8.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 25, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

BARONESS SUTTNER COMING

COTILLON DISPUTE SETTLED

WOLFE APPOINTED COACH

GALLAUDET WINS CLOSE GAME

Well-Known Author and Advocate of
Arbitration to Speak Before Maryland
Peace Society on December 5.

Non-Fraternity Meeting Votes to Accept
One Representative on the Cotillon
Board, and Names J. E. Uhler.

Head Coach of Lacrosse Team—Mr.Edw.
0. Hulburt, Jr., '11, was
Named Assistant.

Hopkins Takes a Slump and Fails to
Hold in Check the Deaf Mutes.
V.'M. I. Game on Thursday.

Baroness Bertha von Suttner, of
Vienna, one of the foremost of European women interested in arbitration, will address the Maryland
Peace Society, on December 5, in
McCoy Hall. Baroness von Suttner is president of the peace society of her country, and vice-president of the International Peace
Bureau of Berne.
The Baroness is one of the most
remarkable women of our time.
She was born in Prague in 1843,
the daughter of Gen. Count Franz
von Kinsky, and his wife, who, before her marriage, had been Fraulein Sophie Korner of the Korner
family to which the famous poet
of that name belonged. In 1876
she married Baron Gundaccar von
Suttner, who died in 1902. She
spent many years in travel with her
husband, and at one time lived for
nine years in the Caucasus.
At the age of thirty-seven the
Baroness turned to literature, and
her first book appeared in 1880.
Since that time she has been an
assiduous writer, and hardly a year
has gone by without bringing forth
some new production of her pen.
In 1891 'she became interested in
the movement for international
peace, and has ever since been
among the most prominent workers
in the peace cause. Many of her
novels have been devoted to spreading the peace propaganda, and she
has become a well known figure at
peace congresses, in this country as
well as abroad.
Baroness Suttner's novel "Die
Waffen Nieder" ("Lay Down Your
Arms") is her most noted work,
and the one that established her as
a leader among workers for peace.
Among others of her books are:
"The Inventory of a Soul," "The
Maschinenzeitalter," "Schad-I der
Qual ;" "Martha's Kinder," a sequal
to "Lay Down Your Arms;" "The
Peace Conference at the Hague, a
Journal," and "Briefe an eineh
Toten." Her memoirs appeared in
1909.

In response to notices posted on
the bulletin-boards by J. S. Dickinson, Charles Leland Getz and J.
Earle Uhler, about fifty non-fraternity men came together last
Monday at one o'clock to decide
whether they would accept the offer of one representative to the Cotillon Board which had been made
by the Cotillon Board the preceding week. Mr. Dickinson presided.
Immediately after the meeting was
called to order, Mr. Getz was recognized. After running over the
history of the Student CouncilCotillon Board negotiations, he proceeded to answer the personal
charges which had been brought
against him, and finished by saying
that it remained for the non-fraternity men then assembled to decide whether they would accept the
Cotillon Board's proposal or present to the President the petition
which had been circulated during
the preceding week.
'Mr. J. Earle Uhler, the next
speaker, first defended himself
against the,charges of inconsistency
which had been made against him,
and then moved that the Cotillon
Board's proposal be accepted .for
harmony's sake.
Mr. Dickinson took the floor to.
speak in favor of Mr. Uhler's motion. He felt, he said, that justice
entitled the non-fraternity men to
more than one representative on the
Cotillon Board. He felt, moreover,
that the attitude which all through
the negotiations had been assumed
by the members of that Board was
high-handed and unreasonable. It
was now in the power of the nonfraternity men, by voting, to reject
the Cotillon Board's proposal and
by resolving to present a petition
to the President to bring the dances
to a close altogether; for this, he
was informed, would be the result
of the presentation of a petition.
By such a result the non-fraternity
men would not be the sufferers.
They could now, however, show the
generosity and good feeling which
they felt toward the fraternity men.
He was sure that none of the nonfraternity men desired to see a split
between fraternity men and nonfraternity men; and even although
the Cotillon Board's proposal did
not give them the representation
they were entitled to, he urged
them to be magnanirnous, and for
the sake of harmony to accept it.
Among others who spoke were
Cochran Supplee, 14; J. E. Richardson, 'i3; R. Gminder, "3; L. J.

was
.\11-. J. Reaney Wolfe,
appointed head coach of the lacrosse team for the, season of 1913,
at a meeting of the Athletic Board,
on Monday, November 18. Mr.
Edward 0. Hulburt, also of 'ii,
was appointed assistant coach.
It is fortunate for the team that
Reaney Wolfe has been appointed,
as his selection is the best that
could have been made. • Wolfe is
a player of long experience and he
has played a star game on all teams
of which he has been a member.
His first appearance on a Hopkins
team was in 1910, when he played
center on the 'Varsity. In 1911 he
played center on the 'Varsity team
which won the championship of the
United States. Last year Wolfe
played with Mount Washington and
alternated between center and third
defence. Not only has he had this
experience in playing, but he has
also been instructor in athletics at
the Country School and the Jefferson School. Another point in favor
of the new coach is the fact that
he is a midfield man, a department
in which Hopkins has been relatively weak for several years. The
members of the team are delighted
with the appointment, and nothing
but approval is heard from those
acquainted with lacrosse affairs.
The assistant coach, Eddie Hulburt, is the logical man to work
with Wolfe. Hulburt has played
close attack, especially, in home and
first attack for three years with the
'Varsity, and in 1911, was captain
of the championship team. Last
year Hulburt also played for Mount
Washington, and was the strongest
man on their close attack. As he
is now a student at the University,
and as Ile has played lacrosse only
three seasons, Hulburt is eligible
this year and will play one of the
close attack positions.
The selection of the coach is a
most important matter, and Hopkins students have good reason to
rejoice at the choice of Reaney
Wolfe as the head coach. May he
lead another team to the intercollegiate championship.

Gallaudet succeeded in defeating
Hopkins in football last Saturday
at Homewood, 16 to 14. The score
indicates a close game, and the play
was fairly even. Hopkins, -however, did not play anything like as
good football against the deaf-mutes
as against St. John's the preceding
week. The work of the Hopkins
team was disappointing in the extreme to the rooters. Many of the
players appeared to be affected with
a feeling of indifference, and they
(lid not display the amount of vim
and spirit that a football team usually has whether it has been winning
its games or not.
Hopkins ought.to have defeated
Gallaudet, although the Washingtonians were playing good steady
football. As a team, the Hopkins
players did not shake off their listlessness until too late. The visiting team was probably slightly
heavier than the Black and Blue,
and man for man,the Kendall Green
squad clearly outplayed its opponents.
The ball changed hands several
times during the first quarter, but
neither team was able to score.
Branham tried a field goal, but his
kick did not carry the pigskin quite
to the crossbar, although his aim
was true.,
Randall, of Gallaudet, scored a
touchdown in the second period.
The mutes carried the ball from the
center of the field to Hopkins' goal
line by forward passes and end
runs. Moore kicked goal.
Branham caught the Gallaudet
kick-off and carried it to the 25yard line. By line plunging and
end runs, the pigskin was carried
into Gallaudet's territory, only to be
lost on downs, after some unsticcessful forward passes. Gallaudet
recovered some of the lost ground
and Moore kicked a goal from the
35-yard line. Hopkins took a momentary brace after the kick-off,
and crood gains were made by all
the Hopkins backs. Bridgeman tallied the first touchdown by slipping
away to the side of the gridiron
without being noticed and catching
a beautifully thrown pass from Bagley. Branham kicked goal. The
half ended with the score io to 7.
Bagley intercepted a forward pass
of Gallaudet's, and not only interrupted the mutes' steady progress
toward the Hopkins goal line, but
he almost scored a touchdown before being tackled. He fumbled
when he was tackled, but Connolly
recovered the ball for Hopkins. G.

Women's Meeting.

On Tuesday, November 26, at 5
P. M., a meeting will be held in
McCoy Hall in the Donovan Room
for the women of the Johns Hopkins University. All women connected with the University are invited to attend. The speaker will
be Miss Wallace, who is a graduate
of the University of Toronto and a
member of the faculty of the first
woman's college in Southern China.

WILSON'S PART IN FOOTBALL
A

"Football Director" at Princeton, and
Head Coach of One of Wesleyan's Best Team.

John Hopkins Press
I.—American Journal of Mathmetics.

A view of President-elect Wilson, '79, in a light that has perhaps been lost sight of lately, even
here in Princeton, has been recalled
by Parke H. Davis, '93, the well
known authority on football.
As long ago as 1878, Woodrow
Wilson took an active interest in
football. In the fall of that year
he was a "football director" at
Princeton and cahirman of the
Board—a body that we would today
know under the name of the coaching committee. Not dnly did this
old Board turn out a championship
eleven, but is even more famous for
inventing many of the fundamental
features that mark the intercollegiate game of today.
Ten years later, Governor Wilson
was head coach of the Wesleyan
eleven, and was responsible for a
team that has been famous in that
college's football annals for scoring
on Yale and defeating the strong
team of the University of Pennsylvania. In 1890 he rendered valuable assistance to Captain Edgar
Allen Poe, '91, in coaching his
famous team, being in no small degree responsible for the remarkably successful eleven of that year.
—Daily Princetonian.

NOTE—The alumni editor wishes
to thank C. P. T. for his ,interest.
. Elgin R. I,. Gould, Ph.D. '86, is
president of the City and Suburban
Homes Company of New York.
He was lecturer at Hopkins from
1892 to 1897.
J. Bancroft Hill, ex-'o9, who left
Hopkins to go to Boston "Tech,"
is now in Elizabeth, N. J., in connection with special engineering
work for the Baltimore and Ohio
Railroad.
One of the debating teams of
Washington and Lee College, which
is to meet North Carolina at Lynchburg next month, is -Bill" Hanzsche, ex-'14, "Bill," who is a senior
this year, has made quite a name
for himself in all lines of college
activities.
The Rev. J. W.R. Sumwalt, D.D.,
has been transferred to Smithfield
Street Methodist Church, Pittsburgh. Dr. Sumwalt has been for
the last five and a half years district superintendent to the Washington district. He is a bachelor
of arts '96 at the Johns Hopkins.
The faculty of the College of
Physicians and Surgeons (Baltimore) last week announced the appointment of Baruch M. Edlavitch,
A. B. 'o6, M. D. '10, as instructor
and associate in pathology.. Dr.
Edlavitch was formerly pathologist
at the University 'Hospital, Iowa
State University.
Prof. George'T. Dippold, former
instructor in Johns Hopkins and
Harvard Universities and for the
last eighteen years a professor at
the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died in Chicago, last Tuesday, at the home of his brother-inlaw,' of arterial poisoning. Professor Dippold was born and educated
in Germany. He instructed in
German at Hopkins during the
academic year 1883-84.
Among those attending the eighth
annual convention of the American
Civic Association at the Belvedere
Hotel last week was Frank A. Wolff,
Jr., A. B. '90, Ph.D. '93. Dr. Wolff
held a University fellowship in
1892. He is attending the convention, not owing to his position as
physicist, Bureau of Standards,
Washington, but rather because of
his general interest in civic uplift.
However, the Association's work in
the honest weight and measure
campaigns appeals especially to him.

"The Track Organization."

Elsewhere in these columns is
the announcement of the organization meeting of the 'Varsity track
team. The date, time of day, and
place, are all most clearly set forth,
which diminish by three, the excuses offered by men who should
attend and do not. These meetings for organization of the regular University teams are affairs not
alone for the members of the previous year's team, but for members
of the incoming class who aspire
to a place on a 'Varsity team and
the subsequent 'Varsity "H," and
also for 8o per cent. of the whole
University. They are meetings
where the greatest congeniality prevails among the older men and the
alumni who attend, and where .the
freshman can gain knowledge of
one more activity of the University,
and meet the men concerned. They
are meetings which are interesting;
plans are divulged, schedules made
known, speeches are made, and the
work of the team gotten under
way. The hour which the meetings
consume would be profitably pent.
There is additional interest in the
meeting on December 3, inasmuch
as the team which will reorganize,"
is practically the same championship team of last year, with prospects of a far better season ahead.

Co-eds' Cozy Corner

Elizabeth B.'s Observations.
To the Editor of Co-eds' Cozy Corner:

I was fairly disgusted when I
saw that Florinda had written that
presuming letter to you two weeks
ago. What right had she to suppose that you wanted to get a letter
from her? I'm glad that I have
been brought up not to write letters
to young men I haven't met.
Florinda has been horrid to me
ever since I was elected general
secretary for the Johns Hopkins
University of the Goucher Fund
Collection Committee. She says I
can't collect a cent for Goucher.
I'll show her. I am going to ask
you to write one of your dear little
editorials, not long, you know, asking each alumnus to contribute $50
to my fund, each professor $30, and
each student $15. That will make
$io,000, and she said I couldn't get
a cent. Won't that be lovely?

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 25, 1912.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
From Mr. Tuska.

NEW YORK, Nov. 20, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—I notice in the issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER of November
18 you state that the smoker of the
New York and New Jersey Alumni
Association is to take place December 13. This is an error. It will
be held on the sixth. In this connection the Executive Committee of
the Association would appreciate it
if the names of any former students
resident in New York or vicinity,
known to your readers, would be
forwarded to the secretary so that
invitations to attend can be sent
them. At the meeting which takes
place on this occasion, among the
important business to be transacted
is the following: Consideration of
reports of committees having in
charge the preparation of biographical catalogue of former students of
the University; committee on permanent rooms for the Alumni; committee on next annual dinner. Will
you kindly give space to this communication. Yours very truly,
BENJANIIN TUSKA.
Waiting "Answered."

NOVEMBER 22, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Your correspondent of
last week, signing himself "Crit-

•*

ically yours, Junior," in censuring
the conduct of the University postoffice, has made a flagrant misrepresentation of the facts.
He claims that every morning
. . . "the crowd [before the postoffice window after 9 o'clock] is
kept waiting while the postmaster
assorts second and third class mail.
Nobody is in a great hurry for
newspapers, magazines, advertisements, circulars, etc., yet there we
must stand, morning after morning unitl the last pamphlet is distributed."
This is not the case. The declaration of the postmaster, verified
by personal observation and experience, is that, whether the second
and third class mail is distributed
or not, the office is open at 9 o'clock
and ally box-holder can secure
whatever mail is in his box at that
time. There is no delay whatever,
unless it be that of being in a
"crowd" or a "congregation," two
words your correspondent employs
to describe the handful of persons
that waits at the window each morning. Very truly yours,
DEFENDER I.

The proof-sheets of the preliminary register for 1912-13 have been
posted on the bulletin-board opposite the Registrar's office in McCoy Hall. The sheets show that
there are this year 199 graduate and
196 undergraduate students in the
academic department of the University. One hundred and sixtynine of the graduates are working
toward a degree, and thirty are attendants on single courses. Of the
undergraduates, 130 are full matriculates, thirty-five are candidates
for matriculation., and thirty-one are
special students. The large number
of special students is accounted for
by the fact that under this title -are
grouped the members of the new
technological department. Of the
graduate students, seventy-four, and
of the undergraduates, seventy,
entered the University this year.
The enrollment of the undergraduates shows an increase of about
twenty over that of last year.

Hopkins"—were some of the expressions which greeted me Sunday

and Blue eleven scored two points
less than Gallaudet.
This Gallaudet game was perhaps the only one we had reasonable hope of winning. Yet in spite
of all this, the number of rooters
to give encouragement to the team
was pitifully small. There were
plenty of fellows at Homewood to
root, but many of these fellows absolutely refused to come up into the
rooters' section. "Freshmen, were

juniors and seniors, who ought to
have spirit enough to do better.
"Smith, aren't you doing any
cheering today?" was asked a sophomore, leaning up against the
fence. The sophomore didn't have
enough courtesy to turn his head
around. These fellows do not lack
spirit, but they do not realize how
much yelling can do to win a game.

yelling last Saturday and he seemed
to think that it had been pretty
good. If anyone had seen the laugh-

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 25, 1912.
WOULD SAVE IN CARE OF INSANE
Lunacy Commission Considers Co-operative Buying Plan—prominent Men
Address the Meeting.

.1

The first step toward obtaining
a system of co-operative buying of
supplies for State institutions for
the insane was taken at the semiannual meeting of the State Lunacy
Commission and the executive officers and directors of the five institutions.
Henry P. Wright, director of the
Bureau of Estimates and Appointments of New York city, who has
helped to unify the purchase of supplies for New York institutions,
delivered an address. Charles J.
Bonaparte, president of the Board
of State Aids and Charities, spoke
on the Board's attitude in connection with expenditures for State
institutions, over all of which the
State Board has supervision.
In many States the labor of patients in hospitals for the insane is
utilized to make furniture for other
institutions; in some cases to raise
food for the tables of the institutions. Much money is saved in this
manner and at the same time the
patients are given employment—
which is better for their health than
idleness.
Members of the Maryland Lunacy
Commission are anxious to see such
a system established in this State in
connection with the big program
they have on hand for bringing the
treatment of the insane in Maryland
up to the standard of treatment
elsewhere.
Dr. Arthur P. Herring delivered
an address illustrated with lantern
slides, telling of the increase of the
insane in the State and the causes
of this increase. Dr. Hugh H.
Young, president of the Commission, spoke. Governor Goldsborough presided.
The meeting was held in McCoy
Hall.

Well-Known Author and Advocate of
Arbitration to Speak Before Maryland
Peace Society on December 5.

Non-Fraternity Meeting Votes to Accept
One Representative on the Cotillon
Board, and Names J. E. Uhler.

Baroness Bertha von Suttner, of
Vienna, one of the foremost of European women interested in arbitration, will address the Maryland
Peace Society, on December 5, in
McCoy Hall. Baroness von Suttner is president of the peace society of her country, and vice-president of the International Peace
Bureau of Berne.
The Baroness is one of the most
remarkable women of our time.
She was born in Prague in 1843,
the daughter of Gen. Count Franz
von Kinsky, and his wife, who, before her marriage, had been Fraulein Sophie Korner of the Korner
family to which the famous poet
of that name belonged. In 1876
she married Baron Gundaccar von
Suttner, who died in 1902. She
spent many years in travel with her
husband, and at one time lived for
nine years in the Caucasus.
At the age of thirty-seven the
Baroness turned to literature, and
her first book appeared in 1880.
Since that time she has been an
assiduous writer, and hardly a year
has gone by without bringing forth
some new production of her pen.
In 1891 'she became interested in
the movement for international
peace, and has ever since been
among the most prominent workers
in the peace cause. Many of her
novels have been devoted to spreading the peace propaganda, and she
has become a well known figure at
peace congresses, in this country as
well as abroad.
Baroness Suttner's novel "Die
Waffen Nieder" ("Lay Down Your
Arms") is her most noted work,
and the one that established her as
a leader among workers for peace.
Among others of her books are:
"The Inventory of a Soul," "The
Maschinenzeitalter," "Schad-I der
Qual ;" "Martha's Kinder," a sequal
to "Lay Down Your Arms;" "The
Peace Conference at the Hague, a
Journal," and "Briefe an eineh
Toten." Her memoirs appeared in
1909.

In response to notices posted on
the bulletin-boards by J. S. Dickinson, Charles Leland Getz and J.
Earle Uhler, about fifty non-fraternity men came together last
Monday at one o'clock to decide
whether they would accept the offer of one representative to the Cotillon Board which had been made
by the Cotillon Board the preceding week. Mr. Dickinson presided.
Immediately after the meeting was
called to order, Mr. Getz was recognized. After running over the
history of the Student CouncilCotillon Board negotiations, he proceeded to answer the personal
charges which had been brought
against him, and finished by saying
that it remained for the non-fraternity men then assembled to decide whether they would accept the
Cotillon Board's proposal or present to the President the petition
which had been circulated during
the preceding week.
'Mr. J. Earle Uhler, the next
speaker, first defended himself
against the,charges of inconsistency
which had been made against him,
and then moved that the Cotillon
Board's proposal be accepted .for
harmony's sake.
Mr. Dickinson took the floor to.
speak in favor of Mr. Uhler's motion. He felt, he said, that justice
entitled the non-fraternity men to
more than one representative on the
Cotillon Board. He felt, moreover,
that the attitude which all through
the negotiations had been assumed
by the members of that Board was
high-handed and unreasonable. It
was now in the power of the nonfraternity men, by voting, to reject
the Cotillon Board's proposal and
by resolving to present a petition
to the President to bring the dances
to a close altogether; for this, he
was informed, would be the result
of the presentation of a petition.
By such a result the non-fraternity
men would not be the sufferers.
They could now, however, show the
generosity and good feeling which
they felt toward the fraternity men.
He was sure that none of the nonfraternity men desired to see a split
between fraternity men and nonfraternity men; and even although
the Cotillon Board's proposal did
not give them the representation
they were entitled to, he urged
them to be magnanirnous, and for
the sake of harmony to accept it.
Among others who spoke were
Cochran Supplee, 14; J. E. Richardson, 'i3; R. Gminder, "3; L. J.

was
.\11-. J. Reaney Wolfe,
appointed head coach of the lacrosse team for the, season of 1913,
at a meeting of the Athletic Board,
on Monday, November 18. Mr.
Edward 0. Hulburt, also of 'ii,
was appointed assistant coach.
It is fortunate for the team that
Reaney Wolfe has been appointed,
as his selection is the best that
could have been made. • Wolfe is
a player of long experience and he
has played a star game on all teams
of which he has been a member.
His first appearance on a Hopkins
team was in 1910, when he played
center on the 'Varsity. In 1911 he
played center on the 'Varsity team
which won the championship of the
United States. Last year Wolfe
played with Mount Washington and
alternated between center and third
defence. Not only has he had this
experience in playing, but he has
also been instructor in athletics at
the Country School and the Jefferson School. Another point in favor
of the new coach is the fact that
he is a midfield man, a department
in which Hopkins has been relatively weak for several years. The
members of the team are delighted
with the appointment, and nothing
but approval is heard from those
acquainted with lacrosse affairs.
The assistant coach, Eddie Hulburt, is the logical man to work
with Wolfe. Hulburt has played
close attack, especially, in home and
first attack for three years with the
'Varsity, and in 1911, was captain
of the championship team. Last
year Hulburt also played for Mount
Washington, and was the strongest
man on their close attack. As he
is now a student at the University,
and as Ile has played lacrosse only
three seasons, Hulburt is eligible
this year and will play one of the
close attack positions.
The selection of the coach is a
most important matter, and Hopkins students have good reason to
rejoice at the choice of Reaney
Wolfe as the head coach. May he
lead another team to the intercollegiate championship.

Gallaudet succeeded in defeating
Hopkins in football last Saturday
at Homewood, 16 to 14. The score
indicates a close game, and the play
was fairly even. Hopkins, -however, did not play anything like as
good football against the deaf-mutes
as against St. John's the preceding
week. The work of the Hopkins
team was disappointing in the extreme to the rooters. Many of the
players appeared to be affected with
a feeling of indifference, and they
(lid not display the amount of vim
and spirit that a football team usually has whether it has been winning
its games or not.
Hopkins ought.to have defeated
Gallaudet, although the Washingtonians were playing good steady
football. As a team, the Hopkins
players did not shake off their listlessness until too late. The visiting team was probably slightly
heavier than the Black and Blue,
and man for man,the Kendall Green
squad clearly outplayed its opponents.
The ball changed hands several
times during the first quarter, but
neither team was able to score.
Branham tried a field goal, but his
kick did not carry the pigskin quite
to the crossbar, although his aim
was true.,
Randall, of Gallaudet, scored a
touchdown in the second period.
The mutes carried the ball from the
center of the field to Hopkins' goal
line by forward passes and end
runs. Moore kicked goal.
Branham caught the Gallaudet
kick-off and carried it to the 25yard line. By line plunging and
end runs, the pigskin was carried
into Gallaudet's territory, only to be
lost on downs, after some unsticcessful forward passes. Gallaudet
recovered some of the lost ground
and Moore kicked a goal from the
35-yard line. Hopkins took a momentary brace after the kick-off,
and crood gains were made by all
the Hopkins backs. Bridgeman tallied the first touchdown by slipping
away to the side of the gridiron
without being noticed and catching
a beautifully thrown pass from Bagley. Branham kicked goal. The
half ended with the score io to 7.
Bagley intercepted a forward pass
of Gallaudet's, and not only interrupted the mutes' steady progress
toward the Hopkins goal line, but
he almost scored a touchdown before being tackled. He fumbled
when he was tackled, but Connolly
recovered the ball for Hopkins. G.

WILSON'S PART IN FOOTBALL
A

"Football Director" at Princeton, and
Head Coach of One of Wesleyan's Best Team.

John Hopkins Press
I.—American Journal of Mathmetics.

A view of President-elect Wilson, '79, in a light that has perhaps been lost sight of lately, even
here in Princeton, has been recalled
by Parke H. Davis, '93, the well
known authority on football.
As long ago as 1878, Woodrow
Wilson took an active interest in
football. In the fall of that year
he was a "football director" at
Princeton and cahirman of the
Board—a body that we would today
know under the name of the coaching committee. Not dnly did this
old Board turn out a championship
eleven, but is even more famous for
inventing many of the fundamental
features that mark the intercollegiate game of today.
Ten years later, Governor Wilson
was head coach of the Wesleyan
eleven, and was responsible for a
team that has been famous in that
college's football annals for scoring
on Yale and defeating the strong
team of the University of Pennsylvania. In 1890 he rendered valuable assistance to Captain Edgar
Allen Poe, '91, in coaching his
famous team, being in no small degree responsible for the remarkably successful eleven of that year.
—Daily Princetonian.

to thank C. P. T. for his ,interest.
. Elgin R. I,. Gould, Ph.D. '86, is
president of the City and Suburban
Homes Company of New York.
He was lecturer at Hopkins from
1892 to 1897.
J. Bancroft Hill, ex-'o9, who left
Hopkins to go to Boston "Tech,"
is now in Elizabeth, N. J., in connection with special engineering
work for the Baltimore and Ohio
Railroad.
One of the debating teams of
Washington and Lee College, which
is to meet North Carolina at Lynchburg next month, is -Bill" Hanzsche, ex-'14, "Bill," who is a senior
this year, has made quite a name
for himself in all lines of college
activities.
The Rev. J. W.R. Sumwalt, D.D.,
has been transferred to Smithfield
Street Methodist Church, Pittsburgh. Dr. Sumwalt has been for
the last five and a half years district superintendent to the Washington district. He is a bachelor
of arts '96 at the Johns Hopkins.
The faculty of the College of
Physicians and Surgeons (Baltimore) last week announced the appointment of Baruch M. Edlavitch,
A. B. 'o6, M. D. '10, as instructor
and associate in pathology.. Dr.
Edlavitch was formerly pathologist
at the University 'Hospital, Iowa
State University.
Prof. George'T. Dippold, former
instructor in Johns Hopkins and
Harvard Universities and for the
last eighteen years a professor at
the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died in Chicago, last Tuesday, at the home of his brother-inlaw,' of arterial poisoning. Professor Dippold was born and educated
in Germany. He instructed in
German at Hopkins during the
academic year 1883-84.
Among those attending the eighth
annual convention of the American
Civic Association at the Belvedere
Hotel last week was Frank A. Wolff,
Jr., A. B. '90, Ph.D. '93. Dr. Wolff
held a University fellowship in
1892. He is attending the convention, not owing to his position as
physicist, Bureau of Standards,
Washington, but rather because of
his general interest in civic uplift.
However, the Association's work in
the honest weight and measure
campaigns appeals especially to him.

"The Track Organization."

Elsewhere in these columns is
the announcement of the organization meeting of the 'Varsity track
team. The date, time of day, and
place, are all most clearly set forth,
which diminish by three, the excuses offered by men who should
attend and do not. These meetings for organization of the regular University teams are affairs not
alone for the members of the previous year's team, but for members
of the incoming class who aspire
to a place on a 'Varsity team and
the subsequent 'Varsity "H," and
also for 8o per cent. of the whole
University. They are meetings
where the greatest congeniality prevails among the older men and the
alumni who attend, and where .the
freshman can gain knowledge of
one more activity of the University,
and meet the men concerned. They
are meetings which are interesting;
plans are divulged, schedules made
known, speeches are made, and the
work of the team gotten under
way. The hour which the meetings
consume would be profitably pent.
There is additional interest in the
meeting on December 3, inasmuch
as the team which will reorganize,"
is practically the same championship team of last year, with prospects of a far better season ahead.

saw that Florinda had written that
presuming letter to you two weeks
ago. What right had she to suppose that you wanted to get a letter
from her? I'm glad that I have
been brought up not to write letters
to young men I haven't met.
Florinda has been horrid to me
ever since I was elected general
secretary for the Johns Hopkins
University of the Goucher Fund
Collection Committee. She says I
can't collect a cent for Goucher.
I'll show her. I am going to ask
you to write one of your dear little
editorials, not long, you know, asking each alumnus to contribute $50
to my fund, each professor $30, and
each student $15. That will make
$io,000, and she said I couldn't get
a cent. Won't that be lovely?

NEW YORK, Nov. 20, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—I notice in the issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER of November
18 you state that the smoker of the
New York and New Jersey Alumni
Association is to take place December 13. This is an error. It will
be held on the sixth. In this connection the Executive Committee of
the Association would appreciate it
if the names of any former students
resident in New York or vicinity,
known to your readers, would be
forwarded to the secretary so that
invitations to attend can be sent
them. At the meeting which takes
place on this occasion, among the
important business to be transacted
is the following: Consideration of
reports of committees having in
charge the preparation of biographical catalogue of former students of
the University; committee on permanent rooms for the Alumni; committee on next annual dinner. Will
you kindly give space to this communication. Yours very truly,
BENJANIIN TUSKA.
Waiting "Answered."

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Your correspondent of
last week, signing himself "Crit-

•*

ically yours, Junior," in censuring
the conduct of the University postoffice, has made a flagrant misrepresentation of the facts.
He claims that every morning
. . . "the crowd [before the postoffice window after 9 o'clock] is
kept waiting while the postmaster
assorts second and third class mail.
Nobody is in a great hurry for
newspapers, magazines, advertisements, circulars, etc., yet there we
must stand, morning after morning unitl the last pamphlet is distributed."
This is not the case. The declaration of the postmaster, verified
by personal observation and experience, is that, whether the second
and third class mail is distributed
or not, the office is open at 9 o'clock
and ally box-holder can secure
whatever mail is in his box at that
time. There is no delay whatever,
unless it be that of being in a
"crowd" or a "congregation," two
words your correspondent employs
to describe the handful of persons
that waits at the window each morning. Very truly yours,

Proof Sheets Out.

The proof-sheets of the preliminary register for 1912-13 have been
posted on the bulletin-board opposite the Registrar's office in McCoy Hall. The sheets show that
there are this year 199 graduate and
196 undergraduate students in the
academic department of the University. One hundred and sixtynine of the graduates are working
toward a degree, and thirty are attendants on single courses. Of the
undergraduates, 130 are full matriculates, thirty-five are candidates
for matriculation., and thirty-one are
special students. The large number
of special students is accounted for
by the fact that under this title -are
grouped the members of the new
technological department. Of the
graduate students, seventy-four, and
of the undergraduates, seventy,
entered the University this year.
The enrollment of the undergraduates shows an increase of about
twenty over that of last year.

enough courtesy to turn his head
around. These fellows do not lack
spirit, but they do not realize how
much yelling can do to win a game.

yelling last Saturday and he seemed
to think that it had been pretty
good. If anyone had seen the laugh-

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 25, 1912.
WOULD SAVE IN CARE OF INSANE
Lunacy Commission Considers Co-operative Buying Plan—prominent Men
Address the Meeting.

.1

The first step toward obtaining
a system of co-operative buying of
supplies for State institutions for
the insane was taken at the semiannual meeting of the State Lunacy
Commission and the executive officers and directors of the five institutions.
Henry P. Wright, director of the
Bureau of Estimates and Appointments of New York city, who has
helped to unify the purchase of supplies for New York institutions,
delivered an address. Charles J.
Bonaparte, president of the Board
of State Aids and Charities, spoke
on the Board's attitude in connection with expenditures for State
institutions, over all of which the
State Board has supervision.
In many States the labor of patients in hospitals for the insane is
utilized to make furniture for other
institutions; in some cases to raise
food for the tables of the institutions. Much money is saved in this
manner and at the same time the
patients are given employment—
which is better for their health than
idleness.
Members of the Maryland Lunacy
Commission are anxious to see such
a system established in this State in
connection with the big program
they have on hand for bringing the
treatment of the insane in Maryland
up to the standard of treatment
elsewhere.
Dr. Arthur P. Herring delivered
an address illustrated with lantern
slides, telling of the increase of the
insane in the State and the causes
of this increase. Dr. Hugh H.
Young, president of the Commission, spoke. Governor Goldsborough presided.
The meeting was held in McCoy
Hall.

Scholarship examinations in October have passed. Word has been
received from Oxford that the two
successful candidates are C. Leland
Getz and Emory H. Niles, both
members of this year's senior class.
